author: Sara Meij and Jonathan Carson
title: Four crash survivors in stable condition in Nelson hospital
text:
Four crash survivors in stable condition in Nelson hospital SARA MEIJ AND JONATHAN CARSON Last updated 10:46, February 28 2017 MARTIN DE RUYTER/FAIRFAX NZ 
Police, fire and ambulance at a double fatality crash near Maisey Rd intersection on State Highway 60, the Coastal Highway. 
Four survivors of a horrific crash near Nelson that claimed the lives of two people are in a stable condition in hospital. 
The fifth survivor has been flown to Wellington Hospital for treatment. 
Two people died at the scene. MARTIN DE RUYTER/FAIRFAX NZ 
The Nelson Marlborough Rescue Helicopter joins emergency services at the scene of a crash which left two people dead on Monday morning. 
The three-vehicle crash happened on the Coastal Highway, State Highway 60, at 10.48am on Monday. 
READ MORE: * Woman describes horrific accident after fatal crash near Nelson 
A scaffolding company truck collided with a four-wheel-drive towing a caravan and a third vehicle near the intersection of the highway with Maisey Rd. 
St John acting shift manager Anne-Marie Harris said an ambulance transported three patients from the scene to Nelson Hospital. 
A 65-year-old woman, a passenger in the vehicle towing the caravan, had a minor head injury. 
A 63-year-old man in the third vehicle had a minor head injury and his 60-year-old wife, also in the vehicle, had moderate back injuries. 
Nelson Marlborough Rescue Helicopter pilot Barry McAuliffe said he transported two men, aged 19 and 28, both from the scaffolding truck, to Nelson Hospital. 
The men, both believed to be from the Nelson region, had serious injuries. 
McAuliffe said the crash scene was one of the worst he had seen in his career. 
"The impact of the vehicles, the destruction . . . it was fairly horrific," he said. 
"Two fatalities and the chaos over the road, it was definitely a bad one." 
Richmond fire chief Craig Piner said one his crews was first on the scene. "It was not a nice scene to turn up to," he said. "You just hone in on what you need to do and you just get on. You make a plan and do your best to help the people out. "That's why we do it, it's to help our community when they need us the most. That's what we're there to do." The Fire Service concentrated on the difficult job getting the two survivors from the truck out safely. "I guess it's good to know you've played a part to help them, hopefully, recover." Piner said a meeting would be held on Tuesday night to talk through the emotional side of working in such testing circumstances. "For some of the crew it's their first time at a major scene like that. It's just good to let them know it's quite normal to be affected by it." 
The police serious crash unit is investigating. 
New Zealand Motor Caravan Association convener Allan James said it was investigating the possibility of the caravan being a member of the organisation, and if it was travelling home from the national rally that was held at the Richmond Park Showgrounds from Thursday to Monday. - Stuff
